alert.note: Alert for Lancaster (South Carolina) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Flood Advisory issued January 09 at 5:31PM EST until January 09 at 6:15PM EST by NWS Columbia
info.description: ...FLOOD ADVISORY IN EFFECT UNTIL 730 PM EST THIS EVENING... * WHAT...Urban and small stream flooding caused by excessive rainfall is expected. * WHERE...A portion of central South Carolina, including the following counties, Bamberg, Calhoun, Chesterfield, Clarendon, Fairfield, Kershaw, Lancaster, Lee, Orangeburg, Richland and Sumter. * WHEN...Until 730 PM EST. * IMPACTS...Minor flooding in low-lying and poor drainage areas. Water over roadways. Overflowing poor drainage areas. River or stream flows are elevated. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 531 PM EST, Doppler radar and automated rain gauges indicated heavy rain due to thunderstorms. This will cause urban and small stream flooding. Between 1 and 1.5 inches of rain have fallen. - Additional rainfall amounts up to 1 inch are expected over the area. This additional rain will result in minor flooding. - Some locations that will experience flooding include... Columbia, Sumter, Orangeburg, Lancaster, Camden, Cheraw, Manning, Bishopville, Springdale, Shaw Air Base, South Sumter, Lake Wateree Dam, Brookdale, Indian Land, Pageland, St. Matthews, Kershaw, Chesterfield, Elgin and Holly Hill. - This includes the following highways... Interstate 95 between mile markers 85 and 146. Interstate 26 between mile markers 141 and 169. Interstate 20 in South Carolina between mile markers 87 and 126. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
info.instruction: Most flooding deaths occur in vehicles. Never drive through a flooded roadway or around barricades. Turn around, don`t drown. Flooded roadways are nearly impossible to see at night. Avoid traveling in this area. Turn around, don`t drown. Be aware of your surroundings and do not drive on flooded roads. Report any flooding directly to the Columbia National Weather Service at 803 234 4115 when it is safe to do so. You can also send reports by Facebook or Twitter to NWSColumbia or by e-mail at NWS.Columbia@noaa.gov.
